Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Naturally produced fungal compounds for sustainable (opto)electronics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will explore a new source of sustainable optoelectronic materials for organic photovoltaics for renewable electricity generation. This project uses bio-derived materials, fungi-derived pigments. An example of such materials is xylindein, which is a blue-green pigment secreted by the non-pathogenic wood-staining fungi Chlorociboria aeruginosa and C. aeruginascens native to the Pacific Northwest of the U.S. This pigment has been used in art since the 15th century, owing to its vibrant color and stability, but its optoelectronic properties have not been explored. In this project, (opto)electronic properties of xylindein and its derivatives will be systematically investigated and incorporated into organic electronic devices such as solar cells. In addition to the field of organic electronics, the project will impact wood products and forestry industries, which stand to benefit from increased commercial potential from Chlorociboria-infested wood having market value. The project will provide a rich interdisciplinary experience involving physics, chemistry, and wood science to the participating graduate, undergraduate, and pre-college students. The outcome of this project is fundamental knowledge supporting organic photovoltaics using these materials and the ability to mass produce the pigments from fungi/biomass resources.

Fungi-derived pigments are abundant; they represent a largely unexplored resource for organic electronics. The goal of the project is to establish photophysical characteristics of xylindein, a planar conjugated fungi-derived pigment, and its derivatives. The project will aim to fulfill the following three objectives: to establish the mechanisms that govern photophysics of xylindein derivatives in solution, to establish effects of interplay between hydrogen bonding and pi-pi stacking on molecular packing and optoelectronic properties, and to explore performance of xylindein derivatives in (opto)electronic devices. Experiments aiming to optimize wood fungi extraction, batch culture growth, and purification will be combined with characterization of molecular photophysics and xylindein-based organic semiconductor devices. The project creates unique opportunities for: (a) the use of bio-derived (low-cost, low-toxicity, abundant) sustainable sources in (opto)electronics; and (b) the possibility to explore synergistic work of pi-stacking and hydrogen bonding for tunable optoelectronic properties via tunability of molecular photophysics and solid-state molecular packing. The results will be important not only for the field of organic electronics, but also for applications relying on hydrogen-bonded pigments that include color printer inks, textile dyes, and commercial paints.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic semiconductors are of interest for (opto)electronic applications such  as transistors, solar cells, light-emitting diodes, sensors, and many others, due to their low cost, solution processability, and tunable properties. Recently, natural product-derived organic pigments attracted attention due to their extraordinary environmental stability and unexpectedly good (opto)electronic performance, in spite of molecular structures that do not follow molecular design rules established for conventional organic semiconductors. Fungi-derived pigments are naturally sourced, sustainable class of materials that are largely unexplored as organic semiconductor materials. In this project, we laid foundations for utilizing such fungi-derived pigments in organic electronics and explored optical and electronic properties of several of such pigments, with an ancient pigment xylindein and its derivatives studied in detail. Our interdisciplinary team of wood scientists, physicists, and chemists investigated various aspects of pigment production, characterization, derivatization, and device implementation.

The results have been communicated in peer-reviewed publications and disseminated via international conference presentations, invited seminars at various US institutions, OSU Innovation Showcase (start-up promotion event for potential investors), and press releases.

Intellectual merit

Xylindein is a spalting pigment secreted by the wood-staining fungi in the Chlorociboria genus (Fig. 1). Thus far, synthesis of xylindein has been unsuccessful, and so this pigment is obtained exclusively from liquid cultures. By optimizing various parameters affecting fungi growth and pigment production, we developed the most efficient procedures for obtaining xylindein with minimized level of impurities, which is necessary for applications in electronic devices, and routes for its scaled-up production. A combination of quantum chemistry calculations, ultrafast spectroscopy, and optical absorption and photoluminescence spectroscopy with measurements of thin-film device characteristics was used to comprehensively investigate photophysics and (photo)conductivity of xylindein.

Xylindein has been used in art and intarsia since the 15th century, and its impressive color retention in these works of art in the present time is a testament to xylindein?s environmental stability.  We showed that in terms of photostability in the presence of continuous illumination in air, xylindein considerably outperformed benchmark organic semiconductors (Fig. 2). The enhanced stability was accompanied by electron mobility of up to 0.4 cm2/(Vs) in amorphous xylindein films (Fig. 3), which is approaching that in amorphous silicon. Methods of improving the quality of xylindein-based thin films, towards high-quality films necessary for electronic devices, were also explored. It was found that blending xylindein with polymer resulted in considerably better film processability and improved morphology, while preserving electronic properties (Fig. 3). By comparing properties of xylindein to those of xylindein derivatives we determined that the presence of hydroxyl (OH) groups in xylindein molecular structure, and the processes they enable, are critical for achieving high photostability (Fig. 2) and conductivity. For example, four orders of magnitude higher charge carrier mobilities were achieved in xylnidein as compared to dimethylxylindein, which is a derivative of xylindein where the OH groups are replaced with OCH3 groups (Fig. 4). Mechanisms of conductivity and photoconductivity of xylindein and its derivatives were also established.  

Broader impact

The methods of efficient and scalable xylindein production developed in this project are important not only for organic electronics, but for a woodworking and art community utilizing spalting pigments (Fig. 5). Mechanisms responsible for enhanced photostability and conductivity of xylindein, revealed in this project, are likely to be relevant for a variety of pigments, as well as for other hydrogen-bonded materials.  

A postdoctoral researcher, seven graduate students, and five undergraduate students from Wood Science and Engineering, Physics and Chemistry have participated in the project, gaining valuable experience in interdisciplinary research which contributed to three Ph.D., two M.S., and three B.S. theses. The researchers involved in the project participated in a variety of outreach activities at K-12 schools across Western Oregon, OSU outreach events such as Discovering the Scientist Within for middle-school girls, and woodworking workshops.
